Cyclist magazine issue 144: on sale now!

So what did you think? Was the new mega-Worlds format a success? Did Glasgow put on a good show? In my opinion, the answer is a resounding yes. For me, this is the new Olympics of cycling.

Of course, the Olympics is still the Olympics of cycling, but you know what I mean. This year’s World Championships was more than just a bundling together of cycling’s disparate formats; it was a unified celebration of all things two-wheeled that brought in a whole new audience and introduced us all to elements of the sport we were previously unaware of (or I was, at least).

The thing I love about the Olympics is that once every four years it encourages us to engage with sports that we couldn’t care less about the rest of the time. I will happily sit up late to watch the quarter-finals of the archery, or marvel at the rhythmic gymnastics, and I feel a glow of pride when Britain scoops a medal in the taekwondo, even though I have no idea what’s going on. The Olympics just has that feeling of being an event – something that demands attention and can bring a nation together in shared experience.

And so it felt this year with the UCI Cycling World Championships. Most years I will get excited about the Road World Championships and keep tabs on the track racing and cyclocross, but I honestly couldn’t tell you when the BMX World Championships are held or who’s in it. The same goes for mountain biking, and as for cycle-ball… who even knew it existed? (OK, just me then.)

This year I found myself scanning the schedules so I wouldn’t miss the artistic cycling qualifiers or the BMX freestyle flatland. And when Britain came top of the medals table, I felt that same buzz I got when Britain came second at the 2016 Olympics.

Once again, Britain showcased itself as a wet and miserable place to hold a cycling event, but the crowds were amazing and the whole thing seemed like a great success. I can’t wait for 2027.

Photo Patrik Lundin

What’s in issue 144?

The forgotten world of Epirus: In the northwest of Greece lies Epirus, a rugged land of lakes, rivers, mountains and ancient villages. Today it remains almost untouched, making it the perfect place to explore by bike

What a wonderful Worlds: The two-wheeled takeover of Glasgow captivated a global audience. These are just a few of the highlights

Col de Peyresourde: A veteran of the Tour de France that helped shape the race as we know it

Inside Unbound: From just 34 riders racing out of a small town in America’s Midwest to the biggest and most revered gravel race in the world. Welcome to Unbound

We’re here to fix things: In the male-dominated world of bike mechanics, one workshop takes a different approach by having exclusively female or non-binary staff, and by encouraging customers to get their hands dirty. Cyclist pays a visit to the London Bike Kitchen

Skye’s the limit: Catch the right day and there are few places in the UK as rewarding to ride as the Isle of Skye on Scotland’s northwest coast
